category: Herbs that Transform Phlegm and Stop Coughing

action.primary: Resolves Phlegm and softens Phlegm nodules

indications: Phlegm Nodules in the neck (scrofula, goiter, sensation of fullness and obstruction in the chest)
Thyroid tumors, tuberculosis, orchitis, lymphadenitis, cirrhosis – with Blood movers

action.primary: Promotes urination, clears Heat and reduces swelling

indications: Adjunct for edema, fistula and Leg Qi

contraindications: Contraindicated for those with Spleen and Stomach Deficiency Cold.
Use with caution for those with Cold Phlegm.
Use only with Excess pathogenic clumping.
interactions: Use with caution with anti-diabetic medications such as insulin, sulfonylureas, tolbutamide (Orinase), glipizide (Glucotrol) and glyburide (DiaBeta/Micronase) as the combination may have a synergistic effect.

useCases: For hyperthyroidism, use large doses for a short time.
For hypothyroidism use normal doses for a long period of time.
Palpable abdominal masses, splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.

notes: Some sources say that this herb clears Heat.
Ecklonia Kun Bu is often combined with Sargassum #{HaiZao} Hai Zao another seaweed, for resolving hard masses.
It has an inhibitory effect on cancer cells and is said ti be invaluable in the treatment of cancer.
It inhibits the growth hormone of tumors.
It is one of the best herbs for treating lymphatic swellings, especially with Hai Zao.
It is usually used for accumulation of Dampness or Phlegm.
For various cancers, decoct 40g of this herb with 1000g wheat for oral administration several times a day.
One source says that masses and goiters as hard as a rock can only be treated with this herb.

Both Kun Bu and Sargassum Hai Zao are similar in properties and actions. Hai Zao is bitter as well as salty and cold. Its flavor is turbid and its cooling action is less than Kun Bu and its therapeutic actions are milder.
One source says that Kun Bu is stronger than Hai Zao and long-term administration cure dysphagia.
Thallus Laminariae Hai Dai has the same properties and functions as Kun Bu and is used interchangeably, but less commonly. Its dosage is 6-15g.
